dialogue.text: (Midnight strikes, and all guests retire back into their chambers.)
What a night. Time to rest.
(The next morning, as dawn barely rises, Elias wakes early and gets ready for the day.)
(Seems like everyone hasn't woken up yet, maybe I can do some exploring)
(As Elias admires the intricate paintings on the walls of the hallway, he was met with one of the servants, Edith, holding a hot cup of fresh tea.)
Good morning, Sir Wakefield. You're up this early. Would you like a cup of tea?
Uh--
(Before Elias can respond, a loud yell echoes through the hallway)
EXCUSE ME! CAN SOMEONE COME TO MY ROOM? I NEED SOME ASSISTANCE WITH MY DRESS!
Yes, My Lady! I will be right there. Excuse me, Sir
(Edith bows, then places the teacup that was in his hands on to a nearby dresser and rushes to Lady Rosalind's bedroom)
(Each side of the hallways were filled with shut wooden doors, it was eerily quiet)
(It seems like not everyone has woken up yet)
(Elias enters the manor's dining hall. It was grand, in there lays a large table with many chairs, with some guests seated already.
Good morning, Mr. Wakefield! Please, have a seat while we wait for everyone else to get ready.
Yes, my lord.
(Elias takes a seat next to Lord Fairfax)
Good day, Detective. How has your morning been?
I'm fine, thank you.
(As chatter erupts in the dining hall, more guests eventually arrive. The woman in red at the ball the night before, took a seat across from Elias.)
Morning, gentlemen.
Morning to you too, Lady Isabella
(Not long after, Lady Rosalind arrived, looking rushed and seated next to Blackwood)
I'm sorry I'm late, everyone. I thought I lost my shoe, and it turns out the maid found it under the bed, haha. Thank you for your help earlier, Edith.
My pleasure, my lady
Hmm, Eleanor isn't here yet. It's strange of her to not be on time. Edith, can you check on her?
Yes, my lord. I shall go to her room.
(Edith then leaves the dining hall, while Perry and Henshaw serve each guest their breakfast platters)
While we wait for Eleanor, please enjoy the food, everyone.
(Not long after, Edith comes back rushing, looking pale)
My lord!
What's the matter, Edith?
It's Lady Eleanor... she's dead, my Lord...
A warm cup of jasmine tea.
